pageContext.title: Pokemon Go is growing again. Here are 3 product lessons we can learn
pageContext.content:
It was a Sunday afternoon in the Bay Area, and I was drawn outside by the warm weather to nearby Burgess Park. Surrounded by basketball courts, soccer fields, a swimming pool, and a skate park, the choice of what to do was obvious: stare intently at my phone.

And I wasn’t the only one. There were hundreds of people like me focused solely on a more interesting virtual world: the world of Pokemon Go.

But isn’t Pokemon Go yesterday’s news? Sure, it may have been popular at one point, but no one actually still plays it right?

It turns out that not only is Pokemon Go doing well, it may be doing better than ever.

Pikachu? Try Pika-cha-ching

The hit mobile game was launched over two years ago on July 5, 2016. It quickly became the number one overall mobile app on both iOS and Android and was the most downloaded App Store app ever. Within its first two weeks, Pokemon Go would also capture the crown of largest mobile game ever in the US with more than 20 million daily active users.

But like other cultural fads, the popularity of Pokemon Go did eventually wane. From a peak of hundreds of millions of monthly players, the user base shrank steadily, eventually hitting 65 million users by April 2017. But that’s also when the game began to prove it’s not like other cultural fads. Those 65 million users stuck around, continuing to spend significant time and money on the game.

And then, something even more unusual happened: Pokemon Go began growing in popularity again.

For its one year anniversary in July 2017, Niantic held its first ever organized event in Chicago and sold out the 20,000 available tickets in minutes. By May 2018, Pokemon Go had more users (147 million) than any month since its launch, and revenues for that month reached US$104 million, up 174 percent from the previous year.

Pokemon Go’s success has been nothing short of spectacular. Even more so when you factor in a little secret about it: the game itself is actually boring.

What is Pokemon Go exactly?

There are three main tasks for players: find, catch, and battle Pokemon.

Finding and catching Pokemon are purely probabilistic — a math equation determines if you are successful at either task, not any user skill. Battling Pokemon is deterministic and requires users to perform a specific action to win.

None of these three tasks factor in user skill, which is why the gameplay is boring.

But that doesn’t mean that the game itself is boring. In fact, the game has hooked me into walking 1,318 km to catch 23,586 Pokemon and counting. Which begs the question, how can I rationalize boring gameplay with a compelling game?

Because Pokemon Go isn’t really a game. It’s a collectible.

Pokemon Go is effectively a digital scrapbook, a sibling of baseball cards, stamps, or coins. With collectibles, it’s the destination, not the journey, that’s important.

The gameplay is not what provides the entertainment. Rather, the result of the gameplay (possessing the Pokemon character) is what engages Pokemon Go players.

Niantic is also in full control of every aspect of the entire collection because it only exists on their servers. Every single Pokemon can be created, deleted, transferred, modified, audited, and repriced instantaneously with lines of code.

Pokemon Go may be a boring game, but it may also be the best collectible ever created.

Product lessons from the game

Around the one year anniversary of Pokemon Go, the game’s product lead Tatsuo Nomura had an interview with the Nikkei Asian Review where he shared an update on the product roadmap.

He also provided insights behind Pokemon Go’s immense success. And if you read carefully, there are three key product decisions that I believe made all the difference.

Using a known brand

“Everybody in every country knows the [Pokemon] character. There is no other such amazing content. Pokemon as a brand has kept expanding.” —Tatsuo Nomura

The Pokemon media brand was recently recognized as the top grossing franchise of all time with a staggering US$85 billion in estimated lifetime revenue. That’s more than Star Wars, Harry Potter, and even Mickey Mouse.

Even before the launch of Pokemon Go, Pokemon itself was already wildly popular. So, while the game has helped take the overall franchise to new heights, its starting point was already sky high.

And it’s not simply the popularity of Pokemon that made it such a great foundation. The media franchise also created a shared history, culture, and value system. It already did the work of creating and explaining the Pokemon universe so that the Pokemon Go user base collectively already knew which stats, scores, and characters mattered.

And that’s the power of a strong media franchise: The followers of the franchise have already been taught the rules and are convinced that they matter. As a product builder, you’re able to start your user journey halfway through, with all the exposition taken care of by someone else.

Using location services

“Traditionally, video games have been played inside living rooms with players sitting on couches. But we hit upon the idea of enticing gamers into spending some time outdoors.” —Tatsuo Nomura

Pokemon Go is an augmented reality (AR) mobile game. But AR actually plays almost no role. In fact, it’s a feature that most players disable because it makes the gameplay slow and inconsistent.

Instead, Pokemon Go is a location-based service, one of the most successful startups ever built on top of the GPS radio in phones (along with Uber, Lyft, and Waze).

Location has played a critical role in the Pokemon Go product evolution:

  1. It dramatically simplified the gameplay by making the real world the game map and you the controller. You didn’t have to learn where to move or how to move within the game.
  2. Location made the game inherently social. You can simply go to a location and see other players, making the community as real as the best games without having to build any features to promote it.
  3. Location is a powerful notification mechanism. Research has shown that humans only visit an average of 25 places regularly. As you play Pokemon Go, you begin to associate landmarks in the real world with landmarks in the game. And since you pass through the same 25 places regularly, these visits become subtle but constant reminders of the game.

Having deliberate constraints

“We want to create a game that hardcore players and casual players can enjoy together.” —Tatsuo Nomura

As I mentioned before, the Pokemon Go gameplay is devoid of skill. But what it is filled with are constraints: certain Pokemon only appear in certain locations, and certain actions can only be performed at certain times.

This is actually a user benefit, as great products are great because of their constraints, not despite them. Tweets have a 280-character limit, Snaps have a 10-second timer, Stories only last 24 hours, etc. These are all intentional constraints that improve user experience.

Pokemon Go’s limitations have been added for a specific purpose: to slow down the pace of the game. Slower play adds friction to the act of collecting, which makes the collectible feel more valuable when achieved.

By making the game more enjoyable at a slow pace, there’s no pressure to get better at the game, which means everyone can enjoy the game to its fullest.

Every app will always have more novices than experts on their service. If you can narrow the experiential gap between these users, you can create more satisfaction and enjoyment for your audience as a whole.

Must all good things end?

Pokemon Go’s hot run has to end soon right? Maybe not.

There are 809 total Pokemon characters in existence today, with approximately 493 available in the game. So by one measure, the app still has 40 percent of its lifecycle remaining. But the Pokemon Company and Niantic recently announced a new Pokemon in the game . So, not only is the Pokemon Go universe not finite, it is easily expandable.

This means Niantic doesn’t have the same pressure to release new features to keep players engaged. As a collectible, Niantic simply needs to do one thing: never run out of things to collect.

With this, millions of passionate collectors will continue venturing from the real world into Pokemon Go. Why? Because, you gotta catch ’em all.

The full version of this article was first published on Medium.
